issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When an image is bundled, uploaded and registered multiple times to the same bucket, Walrus caching issues cause the images to not be unique when launching instances.

Steps to reproduce:

* Bundle, upload, register an image
{code}
$ euca-bundle-image -i raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img --kernel eki-28F338EB --ramdisk eri-51253C0A -r x86_64
$ euca-upload-bundle -b double-raring -m /var/tmp/bundle-1RWjIP/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
$ euca-register -n raring-one double-raring/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
.....
IMAGE	emi-689F35FC	double-raring/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml	441445882805	available	private	x86_64	machine	eki-28F338EB	eri-51253C0A		instance-store
{code}
* Launch an instance based from that image and make sure it gets to running state:
{code}
$ euca-run-instances -k euca-admin -t m1.medium emi-689F35FC
....
$ euca-describe-instances | grep emi-689F35FC
INSTANCE	i-B6A4408A	emi-689F35FC	10.104.7.11	172.17.118.215	running	euca-admin	0		m1.medium	2013-08-26T22:24:01.506Z	LayinDaSmackDown	eki-28F338EB	eri-51253C0A		monitoring-disabled	10.104.7.11	172.17.118.215			instance-store
{code}
* List contents under root user home folder (/root):
{code}
$ ssh -i admin-creds/euca-admin.priv ubuntu@10.104.7.11 "sudo ls -ail /root"
sudo: unable to resolve host ip-172-17-118-215
total 20
 8203 drwx------  3 root root 4096 Aug 26 15:24 .
    2 drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Jul 13 03:38 ..
 3406 -rw-r--r--  1 root root 3106 Oct 28  2012 .bashrc
 3407 -rw-r--r--  1 root root  140 Oct 28  2012 .profile
58919 drwx------  2 root root 4096 Aug 26 15:24 .ssh
{code}
* Mount the image, and add a file under the /root folder:
{code}
$ sudo mount -o loop raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img /mnt/ubuntu
$ sudo cp ec2-all-policy /mnt/ubuntu/root/.
$ sudo umount /mnt/ubuntu
{code}
* Bundle, Upload and Register the Image again using the same bucket
{code}
$ euca-bundle-image -i raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img --kernel eki-28F338EB --ramdisk eri-51253C0A -r x86_64
$ euca-upload-bundle -b double-raring -m /var/tmp/bundle-vtk2jt/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
$ euca-register -n raring-two double-raring/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
....
IMAGE	emi-A5CB3894	double-raring/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml	441445882805	available	private	x86_64	machine	eki-28F338EB	eri-51253C0A		instance-store
{code}
* Launch an instance based from that image and make sure it gets to running state
{code}
$ euca-run-instances -k euca-admin -t m1.medium emi-A5CB3894
.....
$ euca-describe-instances | grep emi-A5CB3894
INSTANCE	i-66EE430D	emi-A5CB3894	10.104.7.12	172.17.118.217	running	euca-admin	0		m1.medium	2013-08-26T22:34:52.406Z	LayinDaSmackDown	eki-28F338EB	eri-51253C0A		monitoring-disabled	10.104.7.12	172.17.118.217			instance-store
{code}
* List the contents under /root.  Should have the new file, but doesn't:
{code}
$ ssh -i admin-creds/euca-admin.priv ubuntu@10.104.7.12 "sudo ls -ail /root"
sudo: unable to resolve host ip-172-17-118-217
total 20
 8203 drwx------  3 root root 4096 Aug 26 15:35 .
    2 drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Jul 13 03:38 ..
 3406 -rw-r--r--  1 root root 3106 Oct 28  2012 .bashrc
 3407 -rw-r--r--  1 root root  140 Oct 28  2012 .profile
58919 drwx------  2 root root 4096 Aug 26 15:35 .ssh
{code}
fields.summary: Running an instance using a modified bundle doesn't behave as expected

comments.body: Performed the same test on AWS. Both instances showed the difference in the file system. The first image, I had ec2-all-policy under /root. The second image, I removed ec2-all-policy and changed it to s3-all-policy under /root: * First image launched {code} $ ssh -i .ec2/personal/personal-keypairs/hspencer-test.pem ubuntu@ec2-54-211-131-21.compute-1.amazonaws.com "sudo ls -ail /root" total 24 8203 drwx------ 3 root root 4096 Aug 27 04:30 . 2 drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Aug 27 04:30 .. 3406 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3106 Oct 28 2012 .bashrc 58858 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 126 Aug 26 22:30 ec2-all-policy 3407 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 140 Oct 28 2012 .profile 58920 drwx------ 2 root root 4096 Aug 27 04:30 .ssh {code} * Second image launched {code} $ ssh -i .ec2/personal/personal-keypairs/hspencer-test.pem ubuntu@ec2-54-242-85-17.compute-1.amazonaws.com "sudo ls -ail /root" total 24 8203 drwx------ 3 root root 4096 Aug 27 05:21 . 2 drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Aug 27 05:21 .. 3406 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3106 Oct 28 2012 .bashrc 3407 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 140 Oct 28 2012 .profile 58858 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 155 Aug 27 04:47 s3-all-policy 58919 drwx------ 2 root root 4096 Aug 27 05:21 .ssh {code} To make sure that there wasn't any funny stuff going on, like the utilization of [S3 object versioning|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ObjectVersioning.html], I tried to launch the first image that I registered, and the instance went to _terminated_ state. I checked the error code and got the _Client.InvalidManifest_ error code: {code} $ ec2-describe-instances i-6a5cc717 --debug -v Setting User-Agent to [ec2-api-tools 1.6.6.0] Setting User-Agent to [ec2-api-tools 1.6.6.0] ------------------------------[ REQUEST ]------------------------------- 2013-08-27T05:29:09.956Z 2013-08-27T05:34:09.956Z  PZ2q004skqoUr0M6muTOFpRFBQ8= SFZR6yczKqqDlNTkh0yCCJ/rHKo= n8LnW6Jweik7aoHCcOchgezBH14HWm+QMpmU+uahn33ncbMuRV0cxkg6PNoh+PfMPExTmXjNW712 SE9WmkhaDRJ325n4Iac2LHOVo4f0g4xuANwLJQtjjPI5MSdXpgjCMvMepW9MRNesOrMx9xL7fiA/ 22LE4VF8SSAxOaM/HdE= i-6a5cc717 ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------[ RESPONSE ]------------------------------ 88e71a66-4043-4251-afd1-5b769e9df9ea r-c7a396a9 986451091583 sg-c09762a8 default i-6a5cc717 ami-81e7a5e8 48 terminated Server.InternalError hspencer-test 0 m1.small 2013-08-27T05:26:04.000Z us-east-1b default aki-88aa75e1 disabled sg-c09762a8 default Client.InvalidManifest Client.InvalidManifest: Invalid image manifest ami-81e7a5e8 x86_64 instance-store paravirtual xen false ------------------------------------------------------------------------ RESERVATION r-c7a396a9 986451091583 default INSTANCE i-6a5cc717 ami-81e7a5e8 terminated(0030) hspencer-test 0 m1.small 2013-08-27T05:26:04+0000 us-east-1b aki-88aa75e1 monitoring-disabled instance-store paravirtual xen sg-c09762a8 default false REQUEST ID 88e71a66-4043-4251-afd1-5b769e9df9ea {code} In short, it looks like whatever was cached previously for the image, once you do a bundle, upload and register of the same image in the same bucket, it invalidates whats in the cache for the image.
I'd have expected the system to store a hash of each bundle's manifest at image registration time and check that every time it gets a request to run an instance of one.

Since the EMIs are different in the two registrations, I don't think this is a back-end bug. [~hspencer], do you know if the first EMI that you registered is still usable on AWS after you uploaded the modified image? (I am wondering if parts of the second overwrite parts of the first.)

Hey [~dmitrii], check the response [here|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-7361?focusedCommentId=52146&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-52146] for more detailed information but in short, you can't use the first AMI registered if you register a new AMI using the same image and bucket.  If you try to run an instance from it, you get a _Client.InvalidManifest_ error code.  Also, I listed the bucket contents after registering the first AMI, and listed the bucket contents after registering the second AMI, and the objects were updated.

*Object Listing After First AMI Registration*
{code}
$ ./s3cmd/s3cmd ls s3://double-raring-images
2013-08-27 04:20      5379   s3://double-raring-images/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
2013-08-27 04:17  10485760   s3://double-raring-images/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.part.00

*Object Listing After Second AMI Registration*
{code}
$ ./s3cmd/s3cmd ls s3://double-raring-images
2013-08-27 05:09      5379   s3://double-raring-images/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.manifest.xml
2013-08-27 05:06  10485760   s3://double-raring-images/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.part.00
2013-08-27 05:06  10485760   s3://double-raring-images/raring-server-cloudimg-amd64.img.part.01

Does this help?

Thanks [~hspencer], great info and investigation. This issue spans both the CLC and Walrus/Image Service. Our current emi registration just tracks the manifest key path. The Walrus/imageservice handling just manages the cache using the same key lookup so you'd likely just get an old version of the object if you've previously used the emi, if the previous emi has not been cached you'd get the new version for both EMIs.

This should be included in the requirements for the new image service being worked on as well.
Possible addition to the image service.
[~kedwards] Where are we at with this issue? Is this going to be handled by development in 4.2?
[~kedwards] Did you see Zach's comments above? I do not think this is a trivial issue.
[~zhill] What is the scope of this issue is this something I can can address in 4.1.1?

[~mmunn1], I don't think this bug exists in the current system because the caching is no longer present in Walrus. The system to look at for this behavior is the image registration system and the imaging worker and if it tracks the checksum of the image as well. I think it does as of 4.1.0 (possibly earlier). If the object is replaced then the object store simply returns the latest version, so it's up to the imaging service to determine if that is valid. I haven't looked in that code to check, but [~vasya] or [~spark] would have more insight on that topic.

[~zhill], [~spark]  Zack is correct this is no longer an issue in 4.1. I have tested this in maint-4.1 using the procedure in the description and I am seeing the file in the newly bundled/uploaded/registered instance. Sang-min can you point me to where this is fixed in the code so that I can update and close this issue as resolved with the correct fixed version.
[~mmunn1] I don't recall fixing this myself.
[~vasya] Do you have any insight to where this was fixed in the code?
[~mmunn1], I think [~zhill] is stating that this issue should not be present in the system due to its redesign. Could you re-test the bug and verify that the issue is no longer present?
[~vasya] I tested this in today 4.1 maint and the issue is resolved.What I am trying to determine is when it was fixed 4.1 or 4.0?
[~mmunn1] redesign was done for 4.0 so I'd bet on 4.0
[~vasya] I will test on 4.0 as well to make sure.
[~mmunn1], yes it should be fixed in 4.0.0 when the Walrus ImageCache was removed.
